image.altText: A mock up of a train on the Suburban Rail Loop

props.synopsis: The multi-billion-dollar plan to build an orbital train link through Melbourne's middle suburbs has drawn its share of both supporters and detractors.

title.children: Visionary project or financial drain? Experts debate the impact of Melbourne's Suburban Rail Loop

image.altText: A white van in a suburban street

props.synopsis: This week, a boy was approached by a man in a white van in Boronia, in Melbourne's east, and a teenage girl in Doncaster ran to a shopping centre after a man in a van asked her to get in.

title.children: Police in Melbourne investigating four separate incidents of children being approached by drivers in a white van

image.altText: A train pulls in to Ballarat station at sunrise. On the opposite platform, a man is silhouetted by the light.

props.synopsis: V/Line has introduced extra services on some lines, but commuters say long-term solutions are needed too, such as platform upgrades and track duplications, to cope with the demand.

title.children: 'Distressing' anxiety incident on packed Ballarat-Melbourne train highlights overcrowding concerns

image.altText: A court sketch of Perry Koroumbilis

props.synopsis: Nearly 48 years after two women were stabbed to death in their Melbourne home, the man accused of carrying out the killings has been charged and faced court for the first time.

title.children: Easey Street accused faces court charged with murder, rape over 1977 killings

image.altText: A sign on a supermarket shelf.

props.synopsis: Workplace Relations Minister Murray Watt urges Woolworths and the United Workers Union to reach an agreement to bring an end to industrial action which has led to stock shortages on supermarket and liquor store shelves.

title.children: Government urges Woolworths and union to end dispute now affecting Dan Murphy's

image.altText: Victorian map showing different areas and rates of family violence, with higher rates shaded in deeper red.

props.synopsis: Data shows people living in regional Victoria are almost twice as likely to experience family violence as those living in metropolitan areas — a shocking gap that is growing year-on-year.

title.children: We took a close look at Victoria's family violence offences data — here's what we found

image.altText: woman with shoulder length brown wavy hair, silver rimmed glasses, and floral print top smiles

props.synopsis: The son of Victorian paramedic Pauline Smith says his family is distraught knowing the driver responsible for her death fled to Queensland ahead of his sentencing.

title.children: Driver sentenced to two-and-a-half years prison for fatal collision that killed beloved small-town paramedic

image.altText: An indigenous woman in a dark green tunic stands in tall grasses near a river.

props.synopsis: The state's civil and administrative tribunal has found that a pro-brumby group racially vilified the former chief executive of an Aboriginal corporation through social media posts and posters.

title.children: Brumby activists racially vilified former head of Yorta Yorta corporation, VCAT finds

image.altText: Jamie stands next to his car

props.synopsis: Over a 10-year period, mental health claims by Australian workers aged between 30 and 40 have increased by more than 730 per cent, new data has revealed.

title.children: 'The worst feeling in your life': Workers lodging mental health claims in record numbers

image.altText: A wall of red and white posters with images of hostages' faces topped with Israeli and US flags

props.synopsis: The Israeli military has said it would not have conducted air strikes in southern Gaza in February had it known the six Israeli hostages were being held nearby.

title.children: Israel says Hamas may have executed six hostages because of nearby Israeli strikes

image.altText: An older man wearing a suit gives a press conference on a humid, cloudy day

props.synopsis: The parliamentary committee looking at the development proposal has voted to make the referral in its report which will be released on Friday.

title.children: Chris Minns says referral to corruption watchdog over Rosehill development 'completely unsubstantiated'

image.altText: A CCTV image of a man holding up a gun on the footpath in Manhattan, wearing a hoodie.

props.synopsis: Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, was on his way to a corporate meeting when he was attacked.

title.children: Manhunt underway in New York after CEO of largest US health insurer shot dead

image.altText: Composite picture of Angus Taylor, Michele Bullock and Jim Chalmers

props.synopsis: Australia's latest national accounts show why we probably would have had to be in recession to have seen an interest rate cut this year.

title.children: What spending would you cut in a 'sad economy without much hope'?

image.altText: A court sketch of a woman with dark skin in a suit wearing handcuffs.

props.synopsis: Australian woman Donna Nelson has been found guilty of trafficking drugs into Japan. Here is how the two-year saga unfolded and what happens next.

title.children: Japanese court finds Donna Nelson guilty, but also a victim

image.altText: With red running track visible in background, a child sits with legs crossed and hands propping up bowed head.

props.synopsis: State and territory governments are under pressure to step in and fund compensation for victims of child sexual abuse as institutions refuse to join the national scheme.

title.children: Deal to compensate child abuse victims of sporting groups failed after just one jurisdiction held out

image.altText: Matildas players congratulate Tash Prior on her first goal for the Matildas.

props.synopsis: Interim coach Tom Sermanni gives us a glimpse of the future he promised, as two streaks end for the Matildas against Chinese Taipei. Here are five quick hits from the friendly victory at Melbourne Rectangular Stadium.

title.children: Five quick hits: Two streaks end for the Matildas as unrecognisable side of young stars scores victory

image.altText: Dash smiles in a crowd at a music festival, the stage behind her.

props.synopsis: Young Australians are taking the opioid reversal drug naloxone with them on nights out. We've unpacked what it is and how it works, and busted some myths along the way.

title.children: 'Everyone was freaking out, screaming': Naloxone nasal spray may save lives

image.altText: A man carries a blue and beige box with Arabic writing.

props.synopsis: An ABC NEWS Verify investigation has found advertisements linking the UN's aid agency in Palestine, UNWRA, with Hamas on Australian websites. It's part of a global ad campaign to discredit the agency.

title.children: UN aid agency slams pro-Israel ads in Australian media that accuse it of funding terrorism

image.altText: Generic TV still of 2 anonymous students writing at school desk at unidentified Qld primary school.

props.synopsis: Girls have fallen behind boys in both maths and science subjects, making Australia's education gender gap the worst in the world, the latest results from a long-running international test show.

title.children: 'Interesting and disappointing': Gap between girls and boys in STEM subjects growing, report shows

image.altText: A series of white pads stitched with colourful patterns.

props.synopsis: A controversy over sanitary pads in China has sparked widespread outrage on social media and ignited a broader debate on gender inequality.

title.children: Sanitary pad sizes in China ignite debate about women's rights

image.altText: Two small boats with divers abroad approach a large underwater shipwreck

props.synopsis: It's two months since the Royal New Zealand Navy vessel Manawanui ran aground and sank off the coast of Samoa — and locals say they can still "smell the fuel".

title.children: 'We're being ignored': Samoan village threatens to sue over NZ Navy ship sinking

image.altText: Allegra Spender

props.synopsis: Eight independents have joined a push to change the definition of "small business" from 15 employees to at least 25.

title.children: Teal MPs want to slash 'regulatory burden' on more businesses as election looms

image.altText: A woman in glasses looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: The financial regulator has taken action against a clothing retailer over concerns the store disputes about exposing vulnerable Aboriginal customers to financial risk.

title.children: ASIC orders NT clothing store to stop letting customers pay through Centrelink deductions

image.altText: A bushmaster vehicle with missile launches attached to the top.

props.synopsis: The Albanese government has approved a tender process that will pit the StrikeMaster mobile missile launcher against the American-made High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS), currently being used by Ukrainian forces.

title.children: Bushmaster missile launchers with a range of 250 kilometres could soon be in place across the Top End

image.altText: A little girl looks up at the camera as she stis on her mother's lap.

props.synopsis: Adeline is a cheeky seven-year-old but her epilepsy has left her brain damaged, and the NDIS won't help, leaving her family desperate for access to therapies that could help her.

title.children: Epilepsy fails NDIS funding criteria because it's not considered a disability, and families are suffering

image.altText: GettyImages-1092905430

props.synopsis: As the World Series stole Australia's best Test cricketers away, an unlikely band of the young and the old came together to take on the might of India.

title.children: Rookies, veterans and the unlikely group of Aussies that brought down India during the World Series war

image.altText: Tjulapi Alison Carroll holding a microphone while sitting in a row of people

props.synopsis: Hundreds of Indigenous doctors have converged from across the globe to share their tips for good health.

title.children: Indigenous doctors from across the globe point to the benefits of first languages in health

image.altText: ASX in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Australian share market has begun its day with very small gains, despite US tech stocks pushing Wall Street to fresh records, while the Australian dollar fell as low as 64 US cents overnight. Follow live.

title.children: ASX rises slightly, tech stocks drive Wall Street to new record highs

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Mining and energy stocks weigh on market, ASX opens relatively flat
Regulator ASIC puts insurers 'on notice' over claims handling

image.altText: Smoke billows from a neighbourhood in a Syrian city with a mosque in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Islamist rebels have been advancing through large swathes of the country's north-west in the past week, threatening the rule of Syria's long-time president, Bashar Al-Assad.

title.children: Syrian forces attempt to defend strategic city after rebels stage biggest advance in years

image.altText: Flash flooding

props.synopsis: Wild weather has lashed south-east Queensland, causing experts to warn about Brisbane's drain network, with some claiming it "isn't designed to take in flows" from intense heavy rainfall.

title.children: Wet summer forecast raises questions about how Brisbane drains handle intense rainfall

image.altText: A mock up of a train on the Suburban Rail Loop

props.synopsis: The multi-billion-dollar plan to build an orbital train link through Melbourne's middle suburbs has drawn its share of both supporters and detractors.

title.children: Visionary project or financial drain? Experts debate the impact of Melbourne's Suburban Rail Loop

image.altText: An image of an elderly woman on a reclining chair with a dog and her adult son next to her. They are toasting champagne.

props.synopsis: Each state requires people to have lived there for at least 12 months to access voluntary assisted dying. Linda was the first person in NSW to receive an exemption to this rule.

title.children: Almost 400 people have died via voluntary assisted dying in NSW in the past year. Linda was one of them

image.altText: A painting of a green skeleton pouring a man a green drink.

props.synopsis: Absinthe was once banned in some countries. It's back on shelves, but still courting controversy.

title.children: Absinthe was once banned around the world and the reasons behind this are murky

image.altText: Two women standing on a balcony with the ocean in the back ground

props.synopsis: Meet Sandra and Sandra — one is a tenant and the other a home owner in Australia's first building to integrate private, social, and affordable housing without segregated facilities.

title.children: Stigma-breaking housing model offers dignity for all with owners and renters living side by side

image.altText: A smiling, dark-haired woman behind the bar in a country pub.

props.synopsis: Some publicans in NSW are ready to lose revenue in order to prioritise social connections. Should they be entitled to tax breaks for refusing to allow the destructive force in their venues?

title.children: These country pubs are surviving without poker-machine profits, but it's a battle against the odds
